segments.text: do you remember where you were for the terrorist attacks on 9-11 ?
segments.speaker: S1

segments.text: yes , I was in my apartment in Beijing . Where were you ?
segments.speaker: S2

segments.text: I was at home with my parents in New York City .
segments.speaker: S1

segments.text: really ? Did you see the hijacked planes crash into and destroy the twin towers ?
segments.speaker: S2

segments.text: I didn't see the crash itself , but I did see the smoke and everything afterwards from my parents ' apartment building .
segments.speaker: S1

segments.text: that must have been horrible . Did you go out at all that day to see what was going on ?
segments.speaker: S2

segments.text: no , we decided to stay in our apartment . With all the buses out of service and the underground trains at a halt , many people had no choice but to walk home . It was utter chaos .
segments.speaker: S1

segments.text: did you know anyone who worked in the World Trade Center ?
segments.speaker: S2

segments.text: yes , my uncle's firm had an office in one of the towers .
segments.speaker: S1

segments.text: unfortunately , he wasn't able to evacuate in time . He ended up dying in the tower .
segments.speaker: S1

segments.text: I'm sorry . That must have really been a nightmarish day for you and your family .
segments.speaker: S2

segments.text: it was . The hijackers didn't have any respect for human life not even their own .
segments.speaker: S1

segments.text: terrorist acts are deliberate and deadly and can affect every walk of life .
segments.speaker: S2
